summary: most common reasons for antimicrobial use in cow-calf operations are respiratory disease and diarrhea in calves before weaning, respiratory disease in calves after weaning, and lameness in cows and bulls (2). a recent survey of 148 veterinarians from the united states and Canada who provided service to cow-calf clients summarized vaccine recommendations for calves at branding, weaning, post-weaning and annual vaccinations for breeding females. the most common target of vaccination was leptospirosis (32%) followed by BVDV (28%) and IBR (25%), and in bulls it was BVDV (24%) followed by leptospirosis (21%). the next available Canadian data resulted from a 2010 survey of 310 producers (14) the first section measured vaccine use between January 1, 2016 and December 31, 2016 in 4 production groups: bulls, cows, unweaned calves, and weaned calves. the second section asked about diseases of most concern when choosing vaccines, producer motivations for vaccine use, factors influencing vaccine choices, and primary sources of information on vaccines. product names as reported by producers were manually linked to a list of vaccines licensed for use in Canada. additional details, including information on specific clostridial vaccine components, were obtained directly from individual product packaging materials. a paper-based survey was developed to assess vaccine use. national census data was used to target selection of cow-calf herds for the network within each province with the goal of matching reported distribution of herd sizes and herd density. veterinarians were asked to identify potential participants from their beef cattle clientele who pregnancy-checked and maintained basic calving and production records. 106 participants responded to the network within the previous 12 mo. thirty-seven percent of respondents (34/93) had > 300 cows and heifers. only 1 herd reported using a monovalent bacterin for Campylobacter fetus spp. venerealis in cows. all products containing leptospira antigens were combined with ML viral vaccines. 93 cow-calf herds reported as the proportion of herds (and number of herds) ML viral vaccines used from January 1 to December 31, 2016. respiratory viruses. most herd owners reported a second or booster dose of calf scours vaccination for replacement heifers. no producers reported use of IN vaccines in replacement heifers. the most common targets of vaccination were clostridial diseases in calves before and after weaning, followed by respiratory viruses. before weaning, boosting was reported more frequently for respiratory virus vaccines than for other vaccine types. 93 cow-calf herds reported as the proportion of herds (and number of herds) producers most likely to rank reproductive and viral respiratory diseases in their list of top 3 concerns motivating vaccination in bulls, cows, and replacement heifers. % of herds ranking each disease in top 3 reasons for concern. % of herds ranking each disease in top 3 reasons for concern. the importance of the disease in the herd and economic benefits of the vaccines were most often ranked in the top 3 reasons for deciding which vaccines to use, followed by the potential of the vaccine to minimize treatment rates and antimicrobial resistance. websites and social media were ranked as important sources of information by a much smaller proportion of participants. 79 were from herds first enrolled in 2014, 4 from herds first enrolled in 2015, and 10 from 2016. median herd size at the start of calving in 2016 was 230 cows and heifers. thirty-seven percent of respondents (34/93) had > 300 cows and heifers. only 1 herd reported using a monovalent bacterin in cows. another herd reported using it in bulls. all other herds vaccinating for bovine genital campylobacteriosis n/a 0 (0) n/a Use of killed or inactivated vaccine 0.91 (85) 0.06 (6) 0.22 (20) 0.08 (7) 0.55 (51) 0.66 (61) 0.04 (4) 0 (0) 0 Clostridial vaccines were the third most commonly reported vaccines in replacement heifers after reproductive and respiratory viruses. most herd owners reported a second or booster dose of calf scours vaccination for replacement heifers. only 41% (38/93) of participants reported backgrounding calves, 8% (7/93) having stockers, and 11% (10/93) having a feedlot. most common targets of vaccination were clostridial diseases in calves both before and after weaning, followed by respiratory viruses. more than half of producers who used histophilus and Mannheimia vaccines in calves later boosted the initial dose either before or after weaning. 93 cow-calf herds reported as the proportion of herds (and number of herds) producers ranked viral and bacterial respiratory diseases in their list of top 3 concerns motivating vaccination. producers were most likely to report using vaccines because they had a problem in the past and wanted to prevent it from happening again. % of herds ranking each disease in top 3 reasons for concern. the importance of the disease in the herd and economic benefits of the vaccines were most often ranked in the top 3 reasons for deciding which vaccines to use. the potential of the vaccine to minimize treatment rates and antimicrobial resistance was reported less often. most cow-calf producers reported using at least some vaccines to manage infectious disease in their herds. most common vaccines used in adult breeding herd were for BVDV and IBR. modified live BVDV and IBR vaccines are only available from veterinarians. 85% decrease in fetal infection, 45% decrease in abortions, and 60% decrease in abortions in cattle vaccinated for IBR (3). many of the combined BVDV and IBR products used in adult cattle also protect against other viral respiratory disease such as PI3 and bovine respiratory syncytial virus. more than 80% of producers provided a second dose either before or after weaning. the second dose was provided before weaning in only 32% of herds. some herds were routinely vaccinated with inactivated clostridial vaccines at birth. only 1 herd reported using an IN vaccine for IBR and PI3 at birth. in the 2010 survey, only 1 herd reported using an IN vaccine for IBR and PI3 at birth. in the present study, 8 herds or 9% reported IN vaccines at birth. two large observational studies from western Canada did not find an association between scour vaccine use in cows and heifers and the frequency of treatment for calf diarrhea or calf mortality (11,14). the foot rot vaccine was rarely used in cows and only used by half of the herds in bulls. the study reflects cow-calf clients from veterinary practices in western Canada. the comparisons we report to previous studies are appropriate. but these results may not apply to herds that do not have a strong veterinary-client-patient relationship, smaller herds, and herds from eastern Canada. f diarrhea and foot rot is common, the use of vaccines for these diseases is much less frequent. there is relatively limited scientific evidence on the cost-effectiveness of the vaccines.
